ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I am interested in studying both film and fiction, so this class has been perfect for me. I've discovered new and interesting authors, and become a better writer with Professor Andrew's feedback.
I learned to evaluate film through a literary lens, including works that are not necessarily in a direct relationship with one another.
Much deeper understanding of adaptation theory and ability to critically analyze film and literature adaptations
I learned to do comparative studies of literature and film, and at the same time developed some key skills in analyzing literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very well-organized in terms of what we study each week. The screenings are fun and engaging, and the class discussions are inspiring.
There were very intriguing discussions in class!! Professor Andrew is so knowledgeable on all the books and films we read!

The syllabus was pretty heavily older white male authors and stories, so only the later works were of serious interest to me. I would have appreciated some more student input on the syllabus perhaps, especially since many of our texts were relatively obscure. I did enjoy how we had the freedom to guide in-class discussion based on our interest.

I enjoyed almost every single week of the course, and I appreciate the film selection. Although some weeks the class discussions could have been more engaging, and I assume the reason might have been the insufficient secondary materials we had to analyzing the films and literature.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely! You learn so much about not only adaptation but also the societal conditions that facilitate the interaction of different narratives.
If you are interested in both film and fiction then yes!! Definitely!

There's a pretty heavy reading and viewing load, so it takes a lot of investment to get the most out of this class, but even if you aren't able to complete it all I think this course provides some really valuable insights for anyone interested in writing or filmmaking.

Yes I would recommend this course. It is interdisciplinary in nature and naturally welcomes students from different backgrounds to join. The films and literature selected are all extremely enjoyable to watch and read.
